Article.ArticleTitle: Ozone modified hypothalamic signaling enhancing thermogenesis in the TDP-43<sup>A315T</sup> transgenic model of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

AbstractText: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a devastating progressive neurodegenerative disease, has no effective treatment. Recent evidence supports a strong metabolic component in ALS pathogenesis. Indeed, metabolic abnormalities in ALS correlate to disease susceptibility and progression, raising additional therapeutic targets against ALS. Ozone (O<sub>3</sub>), a natural bioactive molecule, has been shown to elicit beneficial effects to reduce metabolic disturbances and improved motor behavior in TDP-43<sup>A315T</sup> mice. However, it is fundamental to determine the mechanism through which O<sub>3</sub> acts in ALS. To characterize the association between O<sub>3</sub> exposure and disease-associated weight loss in ALS, we assessed the mRNA and protein expression profile of molecular pathways with a main role in the regulation of the metabolic homeostasis on the hypothalamus and the brown adipose tissue (BAT) at the disease end-stage, in TDP-43<sup>A315T</sup> mice compared to age-matched WT littermates. In addition, the impact of O<sub>3</sub> exposure on the faecal bacterial community diversity, by Illumina sequencing, and on the neuromuscular junctions (NMJs), by confocal imaging, were analysed. Our findings suggest the effectiveness of O<sub>3</sub> exposure to induce metabolic effects in the hypothalamus and BAT of TDP-43<sup>A315T</sup> mice and could be a new complementary non-pharmacological approach for ALS therapy.
